parts.text: Well my name is Glenn and I'm going to have a
conversation with Karen stat for visible high
Oral History Project at the New York Public Library It is Saturday
February twenty first two thousand and fifteen and this
is being recorded at the end Haskell Brederode Talking Book Library
in York City. Welcome Karen I'm very pleased that you've come and I
need to start off and tells a little something about yourself.
OK I don't want to start and I don't want to start at the beginning actually but I suppose I
should start where I am now which is retired. OK
but I think I would like to start at the beginning. Of My Life
. And. I grew up.
In. New York.
Cornell. Is where I'm trying to say Cornell New York which is upstate
and the reason that I'm telling you this is that I am blind from birth but my
parents always try to. Give me as much
get me back as much sight as as they could if possible so I always had to wear
. I remember wearing very thick glasses and we
lived in. A. In a place and.
Cornell I'm sorry in an icing.
In upstate that had a great bar Arbor. OK And one of the
things that they thought that I should do is get rid of my astigmatism I
don't know why they thought how they thought that would help. But anyway they thought it would help by
giving me a very thick glasses. Now I can see light
and it's sort of important to me to be able to see what I can see which isn't very
much so I.
Quote lost unquote my glasses but I wasn't
very smart then maybe I'm not now and I always lost in the great
Barbara mother always found
wreckage so I guess I wasn't all that clever or maybe I'm clever
now but anyway I always lost them and
That's the story that I want to tell you about a new work I'm sorry
and I sing about upstate.
Where I lived. I hope you're editing this thing too like you getting mixed up about it
. I'm sorry it was if it was that we lived. We did not live at Cornell. We went to
Cornell and I'm saying we because my father had a Fulbright exchange
and he somehow finagle them into allowing me to come to nursery
school at Cornell they had a.
A test school or something. It was some sort of special school nursery school
that they had for kids and he somehow got me into it so I got to go to
school with him and I got to score a score with daddy every
. Day which was true for one day and it was and and
nursery school was not bad they were they were they were nice to me in the nursery school
And then when I when I was five when I was school age
well to regular school age anyway we moved to New
Jersey and mother and father apparently had checked out the school systems a
lot and they just checked them out apparently for me although they probably expected to
have other kids and were hoping for a good school system to begin with. For everybody I
mean. But the school that they chose for me had a
special program called the Argonne program which most places didn't have a little though
I understand that New York at it as well.
And this was a program in which I was in a regular school and I
had a Braille class that I went to every day and that's where I hung
my hat and stuff like that. That's where all the all the blind people went in
the area. We were bused there. This was quite unusual and it was
certainly before mainstreaming but this was mainstreaming a
lot. So what happened was that when you're little and you're learning
reading writing and arithmetic and stuff like that you spend most of the time in the in the Braille
class with your teacher. The Braille teacher and I spent some of my day
always with my sighted grade and when I got to about fifth or sixth
grade and I. Knew how to read then I knew how to use the.
Arithmetic slate stuff that I spent most of my time with my sighted peers
so I did not. I was not in a blind
setting in any way. There also weren't any blind. People in
Montclair for me to meet or anything like that so I was sort of
. Grown up sighted in school and
sometimes. I was not
always accepted. Kids are sometimes cruel and
people who are different are. Denigrated in all kinds of
problems like that. And I remember I was
in a cooking cooking classes in seventh grade where
they where we were supposed to. When we had like
six kitchenettes and they set up all the ingredients in one place and are supposed to get
all the ingredients and then work with your group and make whatever it is you're supposed to make. And my
mother was very helpful and school was in getting all the recipes in Braille
. But the kids were not very helpful and they did not want to help me find the ingredients
words which weren't labelled in Braille and stuff like that. And so I
spent two years. Washing dishes. They let me do that.
They let me do that and my mother did go to the principal and
talk to them about it
. The principal said oh no we don't have any teachers who would allow I think like that to
happen. So anyway after having said that it has
gone as far as it could.
She did that but I would say that mostly I was OK in
school. And I went through regular school and I went to
regular high school as well.
And then. Then I went to college. And
then I got my dog.
I probably was the only person in New Jersey at least at that time who the
commission suggested the commission for the blind who was working with me suggested that I
should get a dog. The reason for that is that my parents who
were teachers both of them and educated and books were very big in our
house.
The reason for that was they kept asking for me to get mobility and the
commission or whoever was in charge of it then was saying things like she doesn't need it
yet it's going to be soon it's going to be soon it's going to be soon and then it became soon enough for me to have to
go away to college and then my
counselor decided that they had to get a dog which I had planned
to do anyway because my father had to
had done reading when he was in school for somebody who
had a dog from the C.I. and knew about dogs and we had dogs at home and I like
dogs and stuff like that so I had every intention of doing that. But the commission did
not because at that time the commission was getting
paid for. Do with mobility training for people and
so they did not want you to get a dog because at that time the schools were not requiring
mobility training first. Now they are so it probably doesn't matter if
it's from for any commissioned whether you get your mobility or not
because they're going to get paid just the same if you get a dog afterwards. But at that
time it was a big schism and so I'm sure I was
told to get guide and get a guide if
I did that good. Tell me more about college and your college
experience.
You know I don't remember a whole lot about it. But
. I got through it. I typed my
papers Oh I do remember one thing but I don't think this is what you mean.
I had some of my tests orally of course because you
know the teacher had to give them to me and stuff and we had to do it on a one to one basis.
And I did a sociology test. It was really hard and it was in the
summer. I don't remember which summer it was and of course I was
using my dog for mobility and the dog came in there and it was really hot and that
test was so hard and it was so awful and the dog threw up.
Let's just say well
that's what a lot of my classmates do
recently.
But that's not but that wasn't the norm I did get through Culkin and what did you study
. I studied psychology and sociology with a do one thing
I did do that.
And. I then went for my Master's
. In rehab. And
then I. And then I got a job.
In I H B which is oh it's Helen Keller now I'm sorry but it
was it was I to be then and at that time
Probably just like now although not quite so much as now why people were
not terribly accepted in the workplace and I
sent in my resume to somewhere from the paper
you know that was advertising. And my father kept reading to
me that. They kept listing the same job and I kept calling up on it
and finally I called up and he got on the phone or something and they said
to him he didn't believe that I had. The
degree that I had or the commendation
letters but it was mostly the degree that it wasn't possible for a blind person to have done that.
At which point I gave up and I I'm a fighter but I don't fight that how do you feel
like you know fight back. And actually I H.P. had been one of the
places that I had applied to through there and
I went to I went to H.P. and they took me. But of course
the. The. The organization
that I went through didn't get any money because I know I'm
. Sorry it was the other way around the organization. I went to another organization
they did the same thing I had applied on my own and when where and
. You know they accepted me through the organization of course
they had to get paid and they did
. Which is fine even though I had a plan B. This was a
different one this was not the one that said they wouldn't have anything to do with me.
So anyway I got this job and. I worked there
for a while.
Then I took. All kinds of civil service tests. Like
everybody did at the time which they were charging. For now they are now
. Now I don't know how much you have to pay for civil service tests but certainly you wouldn't take every single
one there is especially if you weren't making any money. But at that time they were charging for
civil service tests and I took one.
And everybody took one and. I. Got a job through
there. And I worked for the Department of Labor for thirty one
years. I have had guide dogs all through my
time and. I've always liked
dogs. We had pet dogs. And. I
just like dogs but I also definitely understand
that a working dog is a working dog and plays well. At home and
I play with it and cut all sorts of stuff but when the dog when we're working we're working
that's it. And they have to know that and I think a lot of I know that a
lot of people who have had pet dogs are sometimes say having the
problem of dividing that and it needs to be divided.
But I've gone on a lot of trips and stuff with my dogs. I
want to tell you that I've I had a dog it was my fourth dog and
I went on a trip with him and I was going to visit a friend in
Canada. Who I had met. At a campground. Oh I forgot to
tell you this. I had met her anyway at a campground in Spain and
we stayed. Close together. I got out so I was going to visit her
I was going to visit my brother Mark who is. In
Washington State and then I was going to visit
my cousin in Chicago. I was like going to make the round of comeback trip
. Yeah it was. But anyway the dog
. Was panting. And he was eight.
And I he had gone to a couple of vets. And he just didn't seem right and I've had a
lot of dogs. Even then he was just my fourth one but I've had dogs since then
and he didn't seem right. Anyway turns out he had a liver cancer
. And. He got it on the trip. And I
took him to a vet. In let me
think. Must've been. It must of
been at the vet at my first stop which was in
Calgary Canada. And. He took blood and said
if I don't know why this dog is sick and throwing up its blood looks perfect
and a week later he was sicker and sicker and sicker and sicker and he didn't
. We went to my brother in Washington but I didn't make him
work. I mean I didn't even try to make it work right. I think this is first of all it would be
safe for him and second of all I don't think it could or something and that that
. Said the same thing. That if you didn't see the bloodwork you would
think this was the blood of a well dog but he.
He took X. rays and stuff. And
. I guess it didn't look right. And we brought him home
because there was no that that had no night person on and my brother
is a doctor and so we brought him home and but apparently
He had been twisted around so much for the X. rays they didn't realize how much pain he was
in and he was just a terrible pain the whole night and snapping and just it was like
the worst night of my whole life. I could be near him and
he was brought back to the vet the next day and the vet. Found cancer
and he found cancer and said should be open him up some more and I said no
just let him go. Home. Anyway that course ruin the whole
trip and should not go on to my cousin
in Chicago and told her I wasn't into happiness anymore and I went
to I went to guiding us and I got an I got a dog. They took me which was
really great. What I discovered from this
Thing besides the Besides that there is no good time to die
Having discovered that what I also discovered is when I
got my dogs they would be sort of naughty and sneaky and silly
sometimes and eventually I would say to them OK you can stop being
bad now because you're in no danger of winning the guide dog of the Year
award.
No danger at all.
You can stop the badness and I said that all of them.
But after. The dog. The golden. I
decided that every dog.
Wins the guide dog he he just went through when he tried to guide this
one that was sick and he did everything and he was good and he was
just amazing and I decided after that that every dog wins
guide dog of the year. Every day that it works. And say Oh
I think that was one thing I learned from that. I
. Think about. Schooling which I left out
is that I lived in England for a year my father had a Fulbright exchange
and that's. And in England they have a different school set
up and they they have they have a month's vacation in
between each semester there are three semesters and so what we did
since the whole family went is that we went camping all over Europe.
Wonderful and that's where I'm the first person that I went to visit in
Calgary and we stayed in touch forever. Yeah that was really a nice trip.
It's really a trip. And one of the things I learned about that
school since I told you I had gone to a. Regular school
and. Did not have the socialist socialization
that I think that I think I would have been in school for the blind. I really discovered that I love
being in that school at that time England was not mainstream. I don't know if they are
now but they weren't them and so I had to go to and I certainly
didn't know where to get books and stuff so I had a school for the blind would would have to be it
. Little did I know it would have to be it but anyway that's what I just saw I had
and.
It was beyond belief. It was just so comfortable and super I couldn't
believe it. Just to have everything
. The way you needed it at your fingertips all the time
to know that the books would be available. To know that.
You know that. Everything that you needed was available to you. There were things
about it that that weren't really comfortable but
but that was a great experience anyway.
And that friend of mine the one that I visited in Calgary.
We stayed friends she was younger than I she was. She's.
Two years younger than I or something but anyway we just hit it off and she came to
me and then she learned Braille for a while. I mean we were amazing and I went to I
went to her youngest daughter's wedding. I went there several times to visit her she seen all
my dogs and no I don't think she seen me like but she see
all the time and we just sort of you know have you ever found somebody that
you've ever spoken to that. You made out of seeing them for three years.
But it feels like you saw them yesterday. Just think of what it was.
That's how we are twenty it's weird. Even
now even a couple of years ago she came to visit me and it's the same thing
. It's it's I don't know why that is but anyway
anyway that's kind of the thing.
There isn't a whole lot like you know about me. I'm not special
But what do you have hobbies or particular interests tour since you
grew up in a house. Readers are there certain kind of books that you
prefer other side wants.
Not I can do it now but I read out the whole science fiction section
of the Jewish prayer list to get one.
All I said that's a remarkable. It's
this.
Is
Why. What I didn't tell you I guess is
that I've been involved with the American Council of the blind and in
. Which is an organization of advocacy
for the blind. Before that I did when I moved
here. I joined guide dog users which.
Started actually I moved here in one thousand nine hundred sixty nine which is when I got my job
and so I was a founding member of guide dog users of New
York which is us which grew into a special
interest group of the American Council of the blind and is very
interested in having. Dog issues dogs be
allowed places and we were instrumental.
In writing the law in one thousand seventy six for New
York for guide dog users. Into I think is really great
. And what did they not have a hand what did that
accomplish what was shipped before and what did this school she would then
be what that would do.
I think Morris Frank would have probably been very proud of that lot
. Maurice Frank be. The first Dido
user and start of saying I am sorry for writing one stuff this
hence all it accomplished the fact that
people with guide dogs were allowed to go into.
Any public place into restaurants where they weren't before
into post offices into stores.
But. That doesn't mean they don't try to throw you out still but it means that the law says
that they can't and you can call the police and I have been involved in
situations where.
The police were called. And they had to listen
they have to allow us in movie theaters.
I I have also I have always felt and it doesn't say that in the law
but I have always felt that a dog has to be what's called socially acceptable that has to
be. Not jumping on the tables and not biting
people and running around and looking and all kinds of stuff like that. It has
to be able to lie down quietly like Midnight is under the table here
and just stay here. And it needs to be.
Able to be. In. The.
Room where everybody else is without causing a ruckus or a problem
and I also I tend to feel that if it is they're more
than happy to throw it out. Throw you and the dog out. If you guys are
causing trouble they can leave. And in fact now
that I think about it I was recently on an airplane. I went to Costa Rica with my
family I was coming home and someone came over to me and said that
. They had guide dogs are
. Raised for a year and a half or so by a person by family
it can be a kid in a house or an older person or or.
I think for a change I think it started out by for it being a foreach project which I
think it still is. And this person decided that
their daughter. Needed. To learn responsibility
and they live near Morristown New Jersey so they had thought they had
them raise a seeing eye puppy but I don't think they watched her
very much because at one point in the
restaurant person they were in a restaurant. The whole family was not just
her. Whole family and then the manager came over and said.
I'm sorry but you're going to have to leave because your dog is eating
stuff off the table next to you. Oh my gosh and. This was
right now. There's not a lot of puppies not allowed to do it immediately it has to
at.
Least for guiding eyes it has to be six months old before it can have what's
called its jacket which means that it's allowed in places like that you know what I mean that
you can't just bring a puppy in there whether it's a guide dog going to be a guide dog puppy or not
I mean it's still a wild dog. Yes.
Anyway something so those people had to leave and the dog didn't make it of course.
And. All I could think of was that the person who should be punished
was the dog owner. Where what is the person who was supposed
to be raising this puppy. It's a puppy. The mother in the restaurant
right
. Yeah they were thrown out and I'm glad the manager did that. I'm glad he felt that he
needed to be able to say that I know your dog. I know you're allowed to come in here but
you're not allowed to cause a ruckus right. NICK GREEN that much.
So I guess I've sort of been involved with advocacy
stuff. For a while. And I
. Am interested in doing that. I'm also very interested in listening to
talk about the moment. And.
I guess. Well I guess you can say books have always been a
big problem. Mormons. Where most of the
stuff first.
She's been a big deal in our house. OK. It's it's the
Jewish tradition but I think it's also an educated tradition for books to
always be there. We always have books I didn't always have Braille books because there
usually weren't always throw books around to get nowther. Now now they're easier to
obtain. But we always had print books and I sort of
carry them around and I remember we had some Golden Books for for
kids that had fuzzy pictures that I could feel their involved there in like bar relief
which is enough.
You know to feel to tell OK they were print books and they read them to me but
they were a relief.
And what our parents also did you know that I think about it is that
we all had. At that time. Potato chips were sold in these
big.
A garbage can he things that had lids that pressure
lids. Yet shot garbage cans. I don't think we know what you mean I can't
think of a better word for it. OK Right.
And we were each and so we we all had our
Arm we were allowed to have our own wastebasket and we could choose whatever we wanted on it from our
books our books from a book that was yours. OK So
guess what I have mine of course
. Oh goodness yes yes
and so right. But everybody but we were allowed to you know choose our own thing and again it's
something that you could feel it was really nice.
But books have always been a big deal to us and I am very in
try to be involved with this library. I am on the council of. The Citizens'
Advisory Council of this library. I tried to
. Get stuff. Resolved by for
people here if they need it or help them learn about it or
. Any kind of library stuff.
Because that's all there is to say except that I'm very interested in dogs that they've discovered
so we did discover and so this has been really an interesting discussion
with you when in closing are there certain kinds of things that you would
like to offer his words of wisdom for people who maybe
twenty thirty forty years from now they listen to this
